newsitem.title: USA: Netscape to ease application devolopment.
newsitem.headline: Netscape to ease application devolopment.

text.p: Netscape Communications Corp on Tuesday outlined how it plans to help software developers create reusable modules that can work on a range of computer systems.
The announcement was made ahead of Netscape's third software developers conference, which opens in San Jose on Wednesday.
The strategy is based on work done over years to create pre-built software components that can be easily combined to create computer applications.
Netscape said the components will enable non-programmers to put together their own programs, a critical part of its plans to offer software that works between corporations.

The company is promoting a new software family it calls "Crossware" that can operate between corporate partners like suppliers and customers and between users who have different systems. This capability has been a key element of Netscape's effort to differentiate itself from Microsoft Corp, which stormed into the Internet software market last year and has been battling Netscape head-on.

"There's a very high cost to developing in the old proprietary platforms if you have more than one platform," Netscape executive Eric Hahn said at a media briefing, adding that such heterogeneity is a given for most companies.

Specifically, Netscape said it will support using Sun Microsystems Inc's JavaBeans component model, which is designed to enable software components to work together across platforms, as is Sun's Java programming language.
